description.narrative: The project Ensuring Reproductive Health Rights and Gender Equality for Ethnic Hilly Women in Bandarban aims to combat GBV and the women and girls are enjoying reproductive health rights holistically through people’s participation and engagement of duty bearers. Bandarban is the remotest area consisting of forests and hills with poor transportation and communication infrastructure. Women, adolescents and children are being deprived, neglected and abused resulting discrimination, exclusion and injustice and have negligible influence in decision making processes which is exuberated being ethnic minority identity. The current Maternal Mortality Rate in CHT is 7/1000 (national 4.5/1000) and the lifetime risk of dying from pregnancy and childbirth-related causes is thousand times higher than that of people living in privileged areas. Women and adolescent girls of CHT have a little access to SRHR. Specific objectives of the project are: 1) The rights holders (RHs) and duty bearers are capacitated to defend GBV within the project location. 2) Advocacy initiative for improved legal framework has been commenced to combat GBV and 3) RHs are getting sexual and reproductive health services and education. The project envelopes a total of 4 outcomes and to achieve the objectives:  1) RHs and duty bearers (DB) are aware about the root causes and consequences of GBV, 2) A common understanding has been created on the existing traditional, cultural, value oriented practices and attitude towards women and girls in the community and way forward to change the attitude positively, 3) The RHs and DBs are capacitated to document, reporting and prosecution of GBV and 4) Access to sexual and reproductive health services and education has been created for rights holders. The target groups of the project are ethnic minorities of Bandarban Sadar and Thanchi upazilla of Bandarban district.
This project mainly contributes to results within Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
